Award.AwardTitle: Fabric Evolution and the Development of Ductile Shear Zones
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is well known that deformation is localized to some extent at every depth in the lithosphere in shear zones. The origin and overall mechanical behavior of these shear zones remain poorly understood. To address their role in tectonics, it is important to understand their origin, whether a scar of earlier tectonics events or a spontaneously generated weak zone. A key is to constrain their rheology, and for this, it is critical to understand deformation processes active in ductile shear zones as well as their architecture. This project aims at better constraining, from a theoretical and mechanical point of view, the structure of the lithosphere beneath seismically active faults. Specifically, the project will address the generation of ductile shear zones and their link with the seismic cycle. Using a software developed specifically for this project, the development of a ductile shear zone beneath a strike-slip fault will be simulated, revealing in particular how the shear zone structure, width, and strength are likely to change with depth. This project would address one of the significant weaknesses in current computer models, which is that they do not adequately incorporate deformation localization processes. The project has potential to advance desired societal outcomes through: 1) development of a globally competitive STEM workforce through training of a post-doctoral fellow; 2) increased partnerships through international collaboration; and 3) development of research infrastructure through the development of new open access software that would be available for reuse by others.

The objective of this project is to develop numerical models of the lithosphere deforming in a strike-slip environment. The model will include fabric evolution in the crust and grain size evolution in the mantle to determine the conditions under which ductile flow may localize and form a ductile shear zone. Three kinds of models will be developed in this project: 1) a 1-D column model that couples a local shear zone evolution model; 2) a 2-D antishear model, using the finite element library deal.II, that will follow development a shear zone below a brittle fault; and 3) the same model subjected to episodic loading by earthquakes on the brittle fault. The project will evaluate three different scenarios for localization through the lithosphere. First, spontaneous localization is the only player throughout the brittle as well as ductile levels of the lithosphere to determine how grain size evolution and the development of a layered structure in the ductile upper mantle and mid to lower crust interacts with strain-weakening in the brittle regime to form a lithospheric-scale shear zone. Second, the study will impose a preexisting brittle fault and determine how ductile shear may localize beneath it, a scenario that includes both imposed and spontaneous localization. Finally, the influence of the earthquake cycle, which periodically imposes episodes of enhanced stress on the evolving shear zones, will be considered. These models will provide basic knowledge on the structure, strength, and width of ductile shear zones that may be expected at depth in actively deforming regions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earthquakes take place on faults that cut through the crust and the sometimes the uppermost mantle. These faults are loaded by relative plate motions and perhaps localized zones of weakness, called ductile shear zones, that may exist underneath faults. In general, heterogeneities in the crust can modify how faults are loaded. This project generated predictions of strength heterogeneities and ductile shear zone configuration in the crust

First, we developed a tool, RHEOL_GUI to interactively predict how the strength of rock may vary with depth into the lithosphere. The tool consists of matlab scripts, including a graphical user interface. It includes a database of laboratory-determined flow laws. It is possible to input a lithospheric structure (for example, specify different rock types in the upper crust, lower crust, and the mantle, adjust the thickness of each layer, and associate a temperature profile with the structure) and solve for the strength envelope for this structure. The tool also allows the strength to be integrated with depth and an effective rheology, that is, relationship between strain rate and integrated strength for the specified structure to be calculated.

Using RHEOL_GUI, we calculated the expected strength of the lithosphere at many locations in Southern California and compared it with measurement of strain rate and geodynamical models of stress and viscosity. We find that the fastest deforming regions, along the San Andreas Fault, the Eastern California Shear Zone, and the Gulf of California Rift are indeed the weakest, while the intervening block (Great Valley, Sierra Nevada, and to some extent, Mojavia) are stronger. In detail, though, we find that we would need to consider a more precise estimate of rock type variations with depth to generate reliable strength estimates.

Considering the oceanic lithosphere, where rock types are more predictable, the approach of RHEOL_GUI showed that changes in grain size and serpentinization are able to explain the range of strain rate observed or inferred worldwide. This suggests that serpentinization and grain size reduction play a central role in weakening old oceanic plate and enable the formation of active plate boundaries.

Grain size reduction is often called for as a weakening agent to form a ductile shear zone in the lithosphere, but there has not been a rigorous test or model of shear zone development in this context. We have implemented grain size evolution laws in a two-dimensional model of motion near a strike-slip fault and show that indeed, grain size evolution leads to a localized ductile shear zone. However, the zone of strain rate enhancement (the shear zone) is narrower and deeper than the zone of grain size reduction, which shows that in addition to grain size reduction, local stress enhancement is important.

In addition to these scientific results, RHEOL_GUI has been used at several institutions to teach the concept of strength envelopes and the variation of strength with depth. The design of this tool leads to intuitive, interactive exploration of rheology and lithosphere structure.
